segments.en: Hello, everyone.
Welcome back to another podcast here at EnglishPod.
segments.cn: 欢迎回到EnglishPod的另一期播客。

segments.en: My name is Marco.
And I'm Erica.
And today we're looking at another one of our lessons for English of the past decades, and this time it's the 1990s.
segments.cn: 今天我们将讨论过去几十年的英语课程，这次是1990年代。

segments.en: Well, you know, the 1990s is a little easier for most of us to remember.
segments.cn: 嗯，你知道，1990年代对我们大多数人来说更容易记住。

segments.en: Yeah, I guess it's a little bit more recent.
We're gonna be looking at a lot of language that is still used today.
segments.cn: 我们将看到很多今天仍在使用的语言。

segments.en: Most of these words and phrases are still used today, so they're gonna be very useful and you're gonna sound a lot more native.
segments.cn: 这些单词和短语今天仍然在用，所以它们会非常有用，你会听起来更像本地人。

segments.en: A lot cooler as well, huh?
Right.
So before we get started with this lesson, why don't we take a look at vocabulary preview?
segments.cn: 在我们开始这节课之前，为什么不先看看词汇预览呢？

segments.en: We have two words we're going to hear in the dialogue.
segments.cn: 我们有两个单词将在对话中听到。

segments.en: Now, the first one is a mall.
A mall.
M-A-L-L, mall.
All right, so a mall is basically short for shopping mall.
segments.cn: 好的，购物中心基本上是购物商场的缩写。

segments.en: And a shopping mall is a big building with many stores inside.
segments.cn: 购物商场是一个有很多商店的大楼。

segments.en: Right, so it's like a shopping center.
segments.cn: 对，所以它就像一个购物中心。

segments.en: And our last word for vocabulary preview is gang.
segments.cn: 我们词汇预览的最后一个单词是帮派。

segments.en: The gang.
The gang.
Okay, so a gang is a group of people, right?
segments.cn: 好的，帮派是一群人，对吧？

segments.en: Yeah, it's a group of people.
You can call your friends the gang.
segments.cn: 你可以称你的朋友为帮派。

segments.en: We're gonna go out with the gang tonight.
segments.cn: 我们今晚要和帮派一起出去。

segments.en: Yep, now we sometimes hear this word and it has a negative meaning, right?
segments.cn: 是的，我们有时听到这个词，它有负面含义，对吧？

segments.en: Right, like street gangs.
Yeah, so people who fight and deal drugs and all that sort of stuff.
segments.cn: 是的，所以那些打架和贩毒的人。

segments.en: Right, so it can have a negative and a positive meaning, but it just depends on how you use it.
segments.cn: 对，所以它可以有负面和正面含义，但这取决于你怎么用。

segments.en: Yep, but in the dialogue we'll hear it with a positive meaning.
segments.cn: 是的，但在对话中我们会听到它的正面含义。

segments.en: Right, so that's all the words we have for a vocabulary preview.
segments.cn: 对，所以这就是我们词汇预览的所有单词。

segments.en: Let's listen to this cool and hip dialogue from the 1990s and we'll come back later and explain some words.
segments.cn: 让我们听听这段来自1990年代的酷炫对话，稍后我们会回来解释一些单词。

segments.en: Hey, four eyes.
What's up, man?
How have you been?
Not bad.
Just went to the mall and picked up some junk.
segments.cn: 刚去购物中心买了一些东西。

segments.en: Check out my new Adidas.
Those are dope.
You are gonna be getting mad props from the gang, man.
segments.cn: 你会从帮派那里得到很多赞美，兄弟。

segments.en: Anyways, have you seen Betty lately?
Dude, don't even go there.
That girl started tripping because I went to the movies with Veronica the other day.
segments.cn: 那女孩因为我前几天和Veronica去看电影而开始发脾气。

segments.en: I was like, look, you knew how I was before you got with me.
segments.cn: 我就说，你知道我在和你在一起之前是怎样的。

segments.en: That's right.
You're such a player, man.
segments.cn: 你真是个花花公子，兄弟。

segments.en: Dude, there's Mad Max.
Let's go say hi.
Max, what's up?
Are you okay?
You look like you just saw a ghost.
I got an F in English class.
My life is over.
Dude, you're over it.
You need to lay off the books for a while and have some fun.
segments.cn: 你需要暂时放下书本，去玩玩。

segments.en: Come on, let's bounce.
Where are we going?
Oh, crap.
My dad is gonna go postal when he finds out about this.
segments.cn: 我爸知道这件事后会发疯的。

segments.en: I'm gonna open the can of whoop ass on you if you don't come with me right now.
segments.cn: 如果你现在不跟我走，我就要对你发火了。

segments.en: Okay, okay.
G.
Well, it sounds like this guy's got some problems at school, huh?
segments.cn: 嗯，听起来这个家伙在学校有些问题，对吧？

segments.en: Yeah, he got an F on his paper, but you always can count on your friends to try and cheer you up by doing something.
segments.cn: 是的，他的论文得了个F，但你总是可以指望朋友们通过做点什么来让你开心。

segments.en: Yeah, but they use some really great phrases and vocabulary words.
segments.cn: 是的，但他们使用了一些很棒的短语和词汇。

segments.en: So why don't we look at those now in Language Takeaway?
segments.cn: 那我们现在来看看这些在语言收获中吧？

segments.en: Language Takeaway.
All right, on Language Takeaway, we're gonna be looking at five words.
segments.cn: 好吧，在语言收获中，我们将看五个单词。

segments.en: And well, let's start with the first one.
segments.cn: 那么，我们先从第一个开始。

segments.en: So the guy was talking about his really cool new shoes, his new Adidas, right?
segments.cn: 所以这个家伙在谈论他非常酷的新鞋子，他的新阿迪达斯，对吧？

segments.en: And his friend said, those are dope.
Dope.
Dope.
Okay, so it's pretty easy to understand when something is dope.
segments.cn: 好的，所以当某样东西很酷时，很容易理解。

segments.en: It's really awesome.
It's cool.
Yeah, it's great.
Right, it's great.
So that's dope.
And it's an adjective, right?
So his friend said, those are dope.
segments.cn: 所以他的朋友说，那些真酷。

segments.en: And he said, you're gonna be getting mad props from the gang.
segments.cn: 他说，你会从帮派那里得到很多赞美。

segments.en: Okay, so mad props.
Mad props.
We can divide this word in two.
segments.cn: 我们可以把这个词分成两部分。

segments.en: So let's take a look at the first part.
segments.cn: 所以让我们看看第一部分。

segments.en: Mad.
Mad.
So we understand that mad is angry, right?
segments.cn: 所以我们理解很多是生气，对吧？

segments.en: Yeah, but it can also mean a lot, right?
segments.cn: 是的，但它也可以意味着很多，对吧？

segments.en: Or really.
So if I say you have mad skills.
segments.cn: 所以如果我说你有很多技能。

segments.en: You're really good at something.
Or you can say she has a mad amount of shoes.
segments.cn: 或者你可以说她有很多鞋子。

segments.en: Alright, so he's going to get mad props.
segments.cn: 好吧，所以他会得到很多赞美。

segments.en: Now props is like respect or compliments.
segments.cn: 现在赞美就像尊重或称赞。

segments.en: Yeah, so his shoes are so cool that he's gonna get a lot of respect or a lot of compliments from his friends.
segments.cn: 是的，所以他的鞋子太酷了，以至于他会从朋友那里得到很多尊重或称赞。

segments.en: Exactly.
Mad props.
Mad props.
So they started talking about girls and he mentioned that this girl started tripping.
segments.cn: 他们开始谈论女孩，他提到这个女孩开始发脾气。

segments.en: Tripping.
Tripping.
So to trip.
Right, as you notice, it's tripping.
segments.cn: 对，你注意到的，就是发脾气。

segments.en: It doesn't have the G at the end, which isn't really grammatically correct, but that's kind of the way it's pronounced.
segments.cn: 结尾没有G，这在语法上并不正确，但这就是它的发音方式。

segments.en: Yeah, we would never say the G.
Right.
So if somebody is tripping.
segments.cn: 所以如果有人在发脾气。

segments.en: They're getting really upset.
They're getting really angry.
Right, they're causing trouble.
So why don't we listen to a couple of examples of how we could use tripping for different situations.
segments.cn: 那我们来听几个例子，看看如何在不同情况下使用发脾气。

segments.en: Example one.
Leanne was tripping because I got dirt on her car.
segments.cn: 利安娜因为我在她的车上弄脏了东西而发脾气。

segments.en: Example two.
Even though I apologize for calling her fat, Jeannie was tripping all night.
segments.cn: 尽管我为叫她胖而道歉，珍妮整晚都在发脾气。

segments.en: Example three.
He sent me 43 text messages and called me about 20 times.
segments.cn: 他给我发了43条短信，还给我打了大约20个电话。

segments.en: That guy is tripping over me.
segments.cn: 那家伙在我身上发脾气。

segments.en: Okay, so that's pretty clear.
Tripping.
All right, now moving on to our next word.
segments.cn: 好的，现在我们进入下一个词。

segments.en: They wanted to go somewhere and he said, come on, let's bounce.
segments.cn: 他们想去某个地方，他说，来吧，我们走吧。

segments.en: Let's bounce.
Let's bounce.
I'm going to bounce.
Now, bounce basically means let's leave.
segments.cn: 现在，走基本上意味着我们离开。

segments.en: Yeah.
Let's get out of here.
But we might be more familiar with this word as in like a ball, right?
segments.cn: 但我们可能更熟悉这个词，比如球，对吧？

segments.en: A ball bounces off the floor.
Exactly.
So I guess it's kind of the same.
You kind of bounce off the floor and leave that place.
segments.cn: 你就像从地上弹起，离开那个地方。

segments.en: Yeah.
Let's bounce.
Okay, so for our final word, now this guy who got a bad Mark on his paper, he was nervous about what his dad would say, right?
segments.cn: 好的，对于我们的最后一个词，这个在论文上得了差评的家伙，他对他爸爸会怎么说感到紧张，对吧？

segments.en: Right.
Because his dad was going to go postal.
He said, my dad is going to go postal.
To go postal.
Now, if you go postal, it means you go crazy.
segments.cn: 如果你发疯，意味着你会变得疯狂。

segments.en: Yeah, you really freak out.
You go, you get very angry.
Yeah, like really angry.

This word comes from the 90s because during a time it was very common in the United States that postal workers, mailmen, were going a little bit crazy and, you know, they started shooting people and delivering some strange packages.
segments.cn: 这个词源于90年代，因为在那段时间，美国的邮递员有点疯狂，他们开始开枪和送一些奇怪的包裹。

segments.en: Well, I guess so people who work in the post office maybe don't have the most exciting jobs and that drives them a little crazy.
segments.cn: 我想邮局工作的人可能没有最刺激的工作，这让他们有点疯狂。

segments.en: Exactly.
But now they have a term named after them.
segments.cn: 但现在他们有一个以他们命名的术语。

segments.en: All right, so why don't we listen to our dialogue for the second time.
segments.cn: 好的，那我们再听一遍对话。

segments.en: We're going to slow it down a little bit and then we'll come back.
segments.cn: 我们会放慢一点，然后再回来。

segments.en: Hey, four eyes, what's up, man?
How have you been?
Not bad.
Just went to the mall and picked up some junk.
segments.cn: 刚去商场买了一些东西。

segments.en: Check out my new Adidas.
Those are dope.
You are going to be getting mad props from the gang, man.
segments.cn: 你会从帮派那里得到很多赞赏，兄弟。

segments.en: Anyways, have you seen Betty lately?
segments.cn: 不过，你最近见过贝蒂吗？

segments.en: Dude, don't even go there.
That girl started tripping because I went to the movies with Veronica the other day.
segments.cn: 那女孩因为我前几天和维罗妮卡去看电影而发脾气。

segments.en: I was like, look, you knew how I was before you got with me.
segments.cn: 我说，看看，你在和我在一起之前就知道我是什么样的人。

segments.en: That's right.
You are such a player, man.
segments.cn: 你真是个花花公子，兄弟。

segments.en: Dude, there's Mad Max.
Let's go say hi.
Max, what's up?
Are you okay?
You look like you just saw a ghost.
segments.cn: 你看起来像刚看到鬼一样。

segments.en: I got an F in English class.
My life is over.
Dude, you're over it.
You need to lay off the books for a while and have some fun.
segments.cn: 你需要暂时放下书本，去玩玩。

segments.en: Come on, let's bounce.
Where are we going?
Oh, crap.
My dad is going to go postal when he finds out about this.
segments.cn: 我爸爸知道这件事后会发疯。

segments.en: I'm going to open the can of whoop ass on you if you don't come with me right now.
segments.cn: 如果你现在不跟我走，我就要对你发火了。

segments.en: Okay, okay.
Jeez.
Okay, so I think that was a little easier to understand.
segments.cn: 好的，我想这更容易理解了。

segments.en: You know, we've got a lot of pretty strange words and phrases, some interesting slang.
segments.cn: 你知道，我们有很多奇怪的词和短语，一些有趣的俚语。

segments.en: Yeah, and I want to take a look at this slang now.
segments.cn: 是的，我现在想看看这些俚语。

segments.en: So let's get started with Fluency Builder.
segments.cn: 所以让我们开始流利度提升。

segments.en: Fluency Builder.
Okay, so the guy with the new shoes, he asked his friends, have you seen Betty lately, right?
segments.cn: 好的，这个新鞋子的家伙，他问他的朋友，最近见过贝蒂吗，对吧？

segments.en: Right.
And his friend replied, don't even go there.
segments.cn: 他的朋友回答说，别提了。

segments.en: Right.
He was like, dude, don't even go there.
Don't even go there.
So what does he mean when he says don't even go there?
segments.cn: 那么他说别提了是什么意思？

segments.en: He means don't talk about it.
I don't want to talk about it.
Right.
Don't even touch that subject.
Don't even mention it.
Right.
So if somebody wants to talk about a topic that you think is sensitive, or you don't want to talk about to say, hey, don't don't even go there.
segments.cn: 所以如果有人想谈你认为敏感的话题，或者你不想谈，你可以说，嘿，别提这个。

segments.en: So Marco, what do you think about the new tax law?
segments.cn: 那么马尔科，你对新税法怎么看？

segments.en: Don't even go there.
I don't even want to talk about politics.
Okay, so I think that's that's a really actually quite helpful phrase to avoid talking about an uncomfortable subject.
segments.cn: 好吧，我觉得这是一个非常有用的短语，可以避免谈论不舒服的话题。

segments.en: Right.
So he said don't even go there.
And he started talking about the girl and she was tripping.
segments.cn: 然后他开始谈那个女孩，她很失控。

segments.en: And then he said something interesting.
segments.cn: 然后他说了一些有趣的事。

segments.en: He said, I was like, look, you knew how I was before you got with me.
segments.cn: 他说，我就像，听着，你在和我在一起之前就知道我是什么样的人。

segments.en: Yeah, I really like this phrase.
segments.cn: 是的，我真的很喜欢这个短语。

segments.en: Now I want to focus on the first part.
segments.cn: 现在我想专注于第一部分。

segments.en: I was like, I was like, I was like.
Now you might hear a lot of native English speakers use these three words before they start telling you what they said.
segments.cn: 现在你可能会听到很多以英语为母语的人在开始告诉你他们说了什么之前使用这三个词。

segments.en: So it's like saying, I said or I told him.
segments.cn: 所以这就像是在说，我说了或者我告诉他。

segments.en: Yep.
So this actually is really common, especially with people under the age of 30.
segments.cn: 所以这实际上是非常常见的，尤其是在30岁以下的人中。

segments.en: So why don't we hear a few more examples of how it's used now?
segments.cn: 那么我们为什么不听几个更多的例子，看看它是如何使用的呢？

segments.en: Example one.
This guy caused a car accident.
segments.cn: 这个家伙造成了一起车祸。

segments.en: I was like, you idiot.
You can kill people by driving like that.
Example two.
And then I was like, I hate you.
And she was all like, I hate you more.
Example three.
I told the teacher that I didn't finish my homework and he was like, I'll see you after school.
segments.cn: 我告诉老师我没完成作业，他就像，我放学后见你。

segments.en: So if you're telling a story or you're maybe talking to somebody and you want to explain what you said, you can say, I was like, Hey, what are you doing?
segments.cn: 所以如果你在讲一个故事，或者你可能在和某人交谈，你想解释你说了什么，你可以说，我就像，嘿，你在做什么？

segments.en: And she was like, what?
So you can have an entire dialogue based with, I was like, she was like, we were like.
segments.cn: 所以你可以有一个完全基于对话的，我就像，她就像，我们就像。

segments.en: Okay.
So I was like, it's super, super useful.
segments.cn: 所以我就像，这个超级有用。

segments.en: So now our next word.
Now they saw their friend who got the bad Mark in school and the guy said, dude, get over it.
segments.cn: 现在他们看到他们的朋友在学校得了坏分数，那家伙说，兄弟，别想太多。

segments.en: Get over it.
Get over it.
So if somebody tells you to get over it.
segments.cn: 所以如果有人告诉你别想太多。

segments.en: Stop worrying about it.
Okay.
Or stop thinking about it.
All right.
So if somebody is sad because maybe his girlfriend broke up with him, you would say.
segments.cn: 所以如果有人因为他的女朋友和他分手而感到伤心，你会说。

segments.en: Get over it.
Stop thinking about it.
Let it go.
It's in the past.
Yeah.
And you, you commonly use this for, um, when somebody is upset about a small thing, something they shouldn't worry about.
segments.cn: 你通常会在某人因为小事而感到不安时使用这个，某些他们不应该担心的事情。

segments.en: Get over it.
Now why don't we go on to our final word at the end of the dialogue?
segments.cn: 现在我们为什么不继续到对话最后的最后一个词？

segments.en: They said, I'm going to open a can of whoop-ass.
segments.cn: 他们说，我要打开一罐打人的。

segments.en: Okay.
So to open a can of whoop-ass on somebody.
segments.cn: 所以对某人打开一罐打人的。

segments.en: To open a can of whoop-ass.
Again, let's break this down before we explain it.
segments.cn: 再次，让我们在解释之前先分解一下。

segments.en: Okay.
I think we have to take one step back here.
To whoop someone's ass is to beat them up, right?
Right.
To punch them and hurt them.
Right.
So to whoop somebody's ass.
So if I open a can of whoop-ass, what does that mean?
segments.cn: 那么如果我打开一罐打人的，这意味着什么？

segments.en: It means you're going to beat them up.
So it's just a funny, very informal way of saying like, in this can, I'm going to open it and I'm going to start hitting you or something like that.
segments.cn: 所以这只是一种有趣的、非常非正式的说法，就像在这个罐子里，我要打开它，我要开始打你或类似的东西。

segments.en: Some sort of small man is going to jump out of the can and start hitting you.
segments.cn: 某种小人会从罐子里跳出来开始打你。

segments.en: But it's never literal.
segments.cn: 但这从来不是字面上的。

segments.en: It's not like you're actually going to beat somebody up.
segments.cn: 这并不是说你真的要揍某人。

segments.en: It's just kind of like... It's kind of a joke.
segments.cn: 这只是一种...这有点像开玩笑。

segments.en: Yeah, it's an empty threat.
segments.cn: 是的，这是一种空洞的威胁。

segments.en: All right.
So some really interesting words and phrases in this dialogue.
segments.cn: 所以在这个对话中有一些非常有趣的词和短语。

segments.en: I think we should listen to it for the last time.
segments.cn: 我觉得我们应该最后再听一次。

segments.en: And then we'll come back and talk a little bit more about this great decade.
segments.cn: 然后我们再回来谈谈这个伟大的十年。

segments.en: Hey, four eyes.
What's up, man?
How have you been?
Not bad.
Just went to the mall and picked up some junk.
segments.cn: 刚去商场买了一些东西。

segments.en: Check out my new Adidas.
Those are dope.
You are going to be getting mad props from the gang, man.
segments.cn: 你会得到帮派的赞赏，兄弟。

segments.en: Anyways, have you seen Betty lately?
segments.cn: 不管怎样，你最近见过贝蒂吗？

segments.en: Dude, don't even go there.
That girl started tripping because I went to the movies with Veronica the other day.
segments.cn: 那女孩因为我前几天和维罗妮卡去看电影而失控。

segments.en: I was like, look, you knew how I was before you got with me.
segments.cn: 我就像，听着，你在和我在一起之前就知道我是什么样的人。

segments.en: That's right.
You're such a player, man.
segments.cn: 你真是个花花公子，兄弟。

segments.en: Dude, there's Mad Max.
segments.cn: 兄弟，那是疯狂的麦克斯。

segments.en: Let's go say hi.
Max, what's up?
Are you okay?
You look like you just saw a ghost.
I got an F in English class.
My life is over.
Dude, you're over it.
You need to lay off the books for a while and have some fun.
segments.cn: 你需要暂时放下书本，去玩玩。

segments.en: Come on, let's bounce.
Where are we going?
Oh, crap.
My dad is going to go postal when he finds out about this.
segments.cn: 我爸知道这件事后会大发雷霆。

segments.en: I'm going to open the can of whoop-ass on you if you don't come with me right now.
segments.cn: 如果你现在不跟我走，我就要对你发火了。

segments.en: Okay, okay.
G.
Well, Marco, in the dialogue, I heard one of the guys say, what's up?
segments.cn: 好吧，Marco，在对话中，我听到一个人说，怎么了？

segments.en: But he said it in a really strange way, didn't he?
segments.cn: 但他说得很奇怪，不是吗？

segments.en: Yeah, exactly.
He said, what's up?
Okay, so what's up with that?
So in the 90s, it was popular, instead of saying what's up, you would just kind of double BS and just say what's up.
segments.cn: 所以在90年代，流行的说法是，不说怎么了，而是双重BS，直接说怎么了。

segments.en: And then it became very famous with a TV commercial for a certain beer.
segments.cn: 然后它通过某个啤酒的电视广告变得非常有名。

segments.en: And actually, I remember this commercial during the Super Bowl.
segments.cn: 其实，我记得在超级碗期间看到这个广告。

segments.en: They had this big commercial where everyone was saying what's up in this really strange way, right?
segments.cn: 他们有个大广告，大家都用一种很奇怪的方式说怎么了，对吧？

segments.en: It's still used today informally between friends.
segments.cn: 现在朋友之间仍然非正式地使用。

segments.en: You'll go, hey, what's up?
And what's up?
Yeah, so you'll use it.
So that commercial made it actually quite cool and famous to talk like that.
segments.cn: 所以那个广告确实让这种说法变得很酷和有名。

segments.en: Actually, in SpanishPod, they have a show called Que Pasa, which is like the translation of what's up.
segments.cn: 其实，在SpanishPod，他们有个节目叫Que Pasa，就像怎么了的翻译。

segments.en: Oh, right.
They start each show with like, saying Que Pasa, but it's exactly the same.
segments.cn: 他们每个节目都以Que Pasa开头，但完全一样。

segments.en: So maybe it will become popular in Spanish.
segments.cn: 所以也许它会在西班牙语中流行。

segments.en: Maybe, but I guess only...
Time will tell.
Yeah, that's right.
All right, so really cool stuff.
And as we heard typical music from the 90s, and another interesting thing was the nicknames.
segments.cn: 我们听到了90年代的典型音乐，另一个有趣的事情是绰号。

segments.en: Four Eyes, Mad Max, very popular among young kids.
segments.cn: 四眼，疯狂麦克斯，在年轻人中非常流行。

segments.en: So remember, if you have any questions about this language or anything else about this lesson, come to our website at EnglishPod.com.
segments.cn: 所以记住，如果你对这门语言或这节课有任何问题，请访问我们的网站EnglishPod.com。

segments.en: Right, you can leave all your questions and comments there, and we hope to see you guys there.
segments.cn: 对，你可以在那儿留下所有问题和评论，我们希望能在那儿见到你们。

segments.en: So thanks for listening, and until next time, goodbye.
segments.cn: 所以谢谢你的收听，下次再见，拜拜。
